data.template: If students read more, they will become better {{response}} – as long as they practice good reading {{response}}. This is important because readers need to be exposed to new words or phrases {{response}} in different contexts before it becomes active in their {{response}}. In addition, research (Nation, 2001) suggests that foreign language learners need to understand {{response}} of the vocabulary in a text to have the same comprehension as a non-foreign student. Overall, the more a person reads, the {{response}} they can understand reading texts.

list: This is one of the reasons why most reached university level in their home countries
Fluency in both written and spoken language will only develop with practice.
In fact, international students studying through English are normally already fluent readers in their own languages
Nonetheless, university students are expected to read a considerable amount during a typical week.
International academics, i.e., students, have to do this in a foreign language – English.
Thus, the more students work on developing good reading habits, the more fluent they should become and the more successful they are likely to be in their academic studies.
data.stimulus:
Paragraph reorganisation

 

 

► The last paragraph has been removed from the original text. 

The sentences from the removed paragraph are listed below in the wrong order.
Arrange them in the right order to form a logical paragraph.

Guessing Vocabulary from Context

► Here's an activity to guess the meaning of words by looking carefully at the context.

 

 

Read the below sentences from the text and write the answers in the boxes.
data.template:
1. In the sentence...

"She goes on to provide statistical evidence to back up her claim." (line 7)
Which word means proof or confirmation? {{response}}

2. In the sentence...

"Reading stories in an extensive reading programme will improve reading fluency" (line 11)
Which word means wide ranging? {{response}}

3. In the sentence...

"What is more relevant is the reference to ‘increasing automaticity in processing’ (line 16)
Which word means significant? {{response}}

4. In the sentence...

"Automaticity allows students to retrieve words quickly from memory" (line 19)
Which word means bring back? {{response}}

5. In the sentence...

"It seems safe to assume as well that a wider vocabulary will facilitate reading." (line 22)
Which word means help? {{response}}

6. In the sentence...

"Developing vocabulary and grammar unconsciously through reading is effective" (line 23)
Which word means without thinking? {{response}}

7. In the sentence...

"With growing competence in the language, students gain more confidence. (line 25)
Which word means skill? {{response}}

8. In the sentence...

"They will be motivated to to use the target language and improve their competence." (line 26)
Which word means aim? {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Identifying Word Class

► Identifying word class can help you work out the meaning of a word you don't know.

 

 

1. Match the definitions to the correct word class below (drag and drop).
data.template:
• a word referring to a person, a place or a thing {{response}}
  • a word referring to an action {{response}}
  • a word that describes a person, a place or a thing {{response}}
  • a word used to describe a verb or an adjective {{response}}
  • a word which comes before a noun or a pronoun and shows its relation to another part of the sentence {{response}}
  • a word that is used to replace a person, a place or a thing {{response}}
  • a word that is used to join other words, phrases, clauses or sentences {{response}}

data.stimulus: 2. What's the word class of these words from the text? Write your answers in the boxes.
data.template:
• topics (line 31) {{response}}
  • typically (line 35) {{response}}
  • this (line 41) {{response}}
  • blends (line 42) {{response}}
  • consideration (line 56) {{response}}
  • simply (line 63) {{response}}
  • through (line 76) {{response}}
  • embark (line 78) {{response}}
  • their (line 78) {{response}}
  • only (line 81) {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Summarising the main points of the text. 

► Choose the best word for each gap.
data.template:
In order for students to be prepared for the {{response}} they will have to do on their academic courses, it is important that they develop {{response}} in order to easily retrieve vocabulary from memory. EAP students can expect to work with materials which are sufficiently {{response}} to be of interest to educated readers, as well as matching the {{response}} of texts they will read during their studies, thus expanding students’ general academic {{response}}.

At the same time, they are encouraged to develop their {{response}} skills and to be able to identify {{response}} in the texts they are reading. Normally, university students are reading for a specific purpose, for example, to find {{response}} in a relevant text before attending a {{response}}. Keeping this purpose in mind is essential for helping students to adapt their {{response}} to a specific need.

One key point about becoming an effective reader is to read {{response}} as possible. Research by Nation (1990 and 2001) emphasizes the need to activate as much {{response}} as possible in order to comfortably read and understand academic texts.
